Authors:
Preuttiporn Supaphon, Sita Preedanon, Souwalak
Phongpaichit, Vatcharin Rukachaisirikul
Title:
Distribution and the antimicrobial activities of endophytic
fungi derived from Nymphaea spp.
Abstract:
Studies on fungal endophytes from aquatic plants have
increased attention because they have been shown various novel
compounds. Thus, this study aims to isolate endophytic fungi from
Nymphaea lotus and Nymphaea stellata. Fungal endophyte was isolated from
four surface sterilized segments, leaves, petals, stalks and stamens.
The total of 210 fungal isolates were obtained from 640 segments. The
highest colonization rates were found in petals segments (0.44), while
stamens yielded the lowest colonization rate (0.13). Furthermore,
seasonal influence affects the fungal colonization in their host plants.
Percentage of colonization rate in rainy season (100%) were more
abundance than summer season (38%). Sixty-five isolates were
representative fungal isolates for investigattion their antimicrobial
activity. They were cultured on PDB for 3 weeks. Then, Culture broth and
mycelia were extracted with ethyl acetate and mycelia were extracted
with ethyl acetate and hexane. One hundred and ninety-five fungal
extracts were evaluated their efficiency against ten pathogenic
microorganisms by colorimetric broth microdilution tests. Almost 50% of
extracts inhibited wide spectrum of microbial tests, except
gram-negative bacteria. The most active extracts derived from 8 fungal
isolates. Eight fungal isolates were further identified based on ITS
sequences by using molecular techniques. They were identified as
Fusarium spp. (FNS009, FNS020 and FNL030), Colletotrichum sp. (FNL053),
Apodus oryzae (FNL023), Eupenicillium levitum (FNL036), Penicillium
simplicissimum (FNS024) and Exerohilum sp. (FNS026). CH extract from
Eupenicillium levitum (FNL036) gave the strongest antifungal activity
with C. neoformans and P. maneffei (MIC 0.5 Âµg/ml) and affect cell
morphology of test microorganisms. This finding confirmed that Nymphaea
spp. were novel source of active metabolites.
